title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
6.1 Assumptions Required for Translation

6.1.1 1. Size-Based Representation of Non-Fish Species
Assumption: Marine mammals and seabirds can be represented within mizer’s size-based framework despite not exhibiting indeterminate growth
Justification:

Previous mizer studies have successfully modeled whales
Body size still determines feeding and predation risk
Can represent key processes (consumption, mortality, reproduction) even if growth pattern differs from fish

Implications:

Will need creative parameterization approaches
May use narrow size ranges or discrete size classes
Growth parameters will represent maturation rather than continuous growth



6.1.2 2. Combining EwE Krill Stanzas
Assumption: EwE’s two krill stanzas (small <24 months, large ≥24 months) can be combined into a single size-structured species
Justification:

Mizer naturally represents size structure and growth through size classes
Von Bertalanffy growth parameters (K = 0.44) can describe transition from small to large
Size-based predation will automatically capture preferential predation on smaller vs. larger krill

Implications:

Need to ensure size-based feeding kernels capture the diet differences between krill sizes in EwE
May need to calibrate recruitment to match total krill biomass



6.1.3 3. Aggregation of Plankton Groups
Assumption: Multiple EwE plankton groups can be aggregated into continuous resource spectra
Justification:

Standard mizer approach for lower trophic levels
Size-based spectra can represent size diversity within functional groups
Forcing data (ISIMIP) provides phytoplankton and zooplankton abundances

Implications:

Lose discrete functional group representation
Cannot explicitly model shifts between phytoplankton types
Resource dynamics simplified compared to EwE



6.1.4 4. Detritus Pathway
Assumption: Detrital pathway can be represented implicitly through resource dynamics
Justification:

Mizer does not explicitly model detritus
Natural mortality and unassimilated consumption contribute to nutrient recycling
Resource regeneration can implicitly represent detrital remineralization

Implications:

Cannot explicitly track detritus pools
May underestimate importance of detrital pathway for benthic communities
energy flow through detritus is implicit rather than explicit



6.1.5 5. Spatial Homogeneity
Assumption: Statistical Subarea 48.1 is treated as spatially homogeneous (well-mixed)
Justification:

EwE model (non-Ecospace version) also assumes spatial homogeneity
Consistent with EwE approach being translated
Forcing data are area-averaged

Implications:

Cannot represent spatial heterogeneity in krill distribution
Cannot model spatial MPAs without extension to spatial mizer
May miss local depletion effects near fishing activity



6.1.6 6. Sea Ice Forcing Translation
Assumption: EwE’s forcing functions and response curves can be translated to mizer’s forcing framework
Justification:

Both models can incorporate environmental forcing
EwE demonstrated that sea ice is critical driver (65% SS reduction)
Mizer can incorporate external factors affecting growth, mortality, or resource availability

Challenges:

Need to research mizer’s capabilities for environmental forcing
May require custom functions or mizerExperimental features
Functional response curves (e.g., sigmoidal krill response to ice) may need creative implementation

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
6.2 Simplifications from EwE Model

6.2.1 1. Diet Matrix to Interaction Matrix
Simplification: EwE’s detailed diet matrix (proportion of each prey in each predator diet) is simplified to species-level interaction coefficients combined with size-based feeding
What is lost:

Age/size-specific diet information within EwE groups
Ability to specify exact diet proportions independent of size

What is gained:

Emergent diet composition based on prey size and availability
More mechanistic representation of size-based predation



6.2.2 2. Biomass Accumulation
Simplification: EwE’s biomass accumulation terms (Humpback whale +3.9% yr⁻¹, Fin whale +2.9% yr⁻¹) need alternative representation
Options:

Adjust recruitment to create population increase
Modify mortality schedules
Incorporate trends in carrying capacity

Implications: Population trends may need to be forced rather than emergent


6.2.3 3. Forcing Function Applications
Simplification: EwE applied forcing functions to specific predator-prey interaction parameters (vulnerability, search rate, arena area). Mizer’s forcing may work differently.
EwE forcing preserved:

Sea ice effects on ice algae and krill
Open water effects on fur seals and gentoo penguins
Chlorophyll effects on primary production

Challenges:

Mizer may not have direct equivalents to EwE’s “arena area” or “vulnerability” parameters
May need to implement forcing through resource availability or mortality modulation



6.2.4 4. Cannibalism
Simplification: EwE explicitly disallowed cannibalism for all groups. Mizer’s size-based predation may allow cannibalism if size ranges overlap.
Approach:

Can set interaction matrices to zero for self-interactions
Or allow cannibalism where biologically realistic (e.g., large fish eating small conspecifics)



6.2.5 5. Multi-Species Functional Groups
Simplification: Some EwE multi-species groups (On-shelf fish, Flying Birds) are represented as single species in mizer
What is lost:

Species diversity within functional groups
Differential responses of component species

Justification:

Insufficient data to parameterize multiple component species
Functional group approach consistent with EwE model’s own approach
Preserves overall trophic role

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
7.1 Parameters Directly Translatable

Biomass (B): EwE biomass (t/km²) → Mizer initial abundances (converted to numbers-at-size using size structure)
Production to Biomass ratio (P/B): EwE annual P/B → Related to mizer growth and mortality parameters

For multi-cellular organisms: P/B ≈ natural mortality M
Will inform background mortality (z0) in mizer

Consumption to Biomass ratio (Q/B): EwE annual Q/B → Informs mizer feeding parameters

Relates to maximum consumption rate and feeding level

Diet Composition: EwE diet matrix → Mizer interaction matrix + size-based preferences
Fishing Mortality: EwE fishing effort and catches → Mizer fishing mortality arrays

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
7.2 Parameters Requiring Derivation

Size-at-maturity (w_mat): Need to derive from literature for each species

Fish: Well-documented for most species
Marine mammals: Age/size at sexual maturity
Penguins: Body mass at first breeding

Asymptotic size (w_inf): Maximum body size

Fish: L∞ from von Bertalanffy growth
Mammals/birds: Maximum adult body mass

von Bertalanffy K: Growth rate parameter

Fish: Available in literature for most species
Krill: K = 0.44 (from EwE model)
Mammals/birds: May need alternative parameterization

Predator-Prey Mass Ratio (beta): Preferred predator:prey size ratio

Derive from predator size and typical prey sizes in EwE diets
Literature values for feeding mode (benthic feeders, planktivores, piscivores, etc.)

Feeding kernel width (sigma): Size selectivity

Specialists: Narrow feeding kernel
Generalists: Broad feeding kernel

Reproductive efficiency (erepro): Conversion of energy to reproduction

Will need calibration to match biomass and recruitment patterns

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
7.3 Research Needed for Marine Mammals/Seabirds
Key questions requiring literature review and potentially consultation with mizer experts:

How have previous mizer studies parameterized whales?
What approaches exist for modeling organisms with determinate growth?
How to represent annual breeding cycles in mizer’s continuous time framework?
What are appropriate size ranges for adult-only representations?
How to handle extreme size differences between nekton and mammals/birds in the same model?

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
8.1 Sea Ice Forcing
Data source: ISIMIP3a siconc (sea ice concentration)
Applications (following EwE Table 3):

Resource Availability Modulation:

Resource carrying capacity can be modulated by sea ice cover
Higher ice → potentially higher resource availability (representing ice algae contribution)

Krill Dynamics:

EwE used sigmoidal response curve (sea ice index → large krill biomass)
Mizer implementation options:

Sea ice affects krill recruitment (R_max or erepro modulation)
Sea ice affects krill resource availability (modulate capacity of smaller resource sizes)
Sea ice affects krill mortality (overwinter survival)

Most realistic: Combination of resource availability modulation + recruitment modulation

Predator-Prey Interactions:

EwE forced Chinstrap-Krill interaction (1.33 SS reduction)
EwE forced interactions for Leopard Seal, Fur Seal
Mizer implementation: Research how to modulate interaction strength with environmental variables

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
8.2 Open Water Forcing
Data source: Can derive from sea ice concentration (open water = 1 - ice cover)
Applications (following EwE Table 3):

Gentoo Penguin feeding:

Open water increases foraging success on on-shelf fish and krill

Antarctic Fur Seal feeding:

Open water increases foraging success (pelagic hunter)

Fish interactions:

EwE applied to C. gunnari and N. rossii interactions

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
8.3 Plankton Forcing
Data sources: ISIMIP3a zooplankton fields (primary) and phytoplankton fields (optional future refinement)

Extended Resource Spectrum (Phase 1 - Current):

Driven by zooplankton data only: zmicro-vint + zmeso-vint
Zooplankton biomass integrates phytoplankton dynamics through trophic interactions
Provides stable, biologically-relevant forcing
Avoids temporal mismatch between phytoplankton boom-bust and zooplankton lagged response

Size-Dependent Forcing (Phase 2 - Future Option):

Small resource sizes (< 1e-6 g): Could be driven by phytoplankton data (phydiat-vint, phydiaz-vint, phypico-vint)
Large resource sizes (≥ 1e-6 g): Driven by zooplankton data (zmicro-vint, zmeso-vint)
Would better capture different dynamics across size spectrum
Requires custom capacity matrix implementation

Chlorophyll-a:

EwE applied chlorophyll forcing to primary production
ISIMIP data are vertically integrated biomasses, may correlate with chlorophyll
Can potentially derive chlorophyll-equivalent metric from phytoplankton biomasses if needed for validation

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
8.4 Temperature Forcing
Data sources: ISIMIP3a tob (bottom temperature), tos (surface temperature)
Potential applications (not explicitly in EwE calibration but ecologically important):

Metabolic rates: Temperature-dependence of consumption and metabolism
Growth rates: Temperature affects growth efficiency
Fish distributions: Temperature may affect habitat suitability (not in non-spatial model but affects parameters)

Implementation: Mizer has built-in temperature dependence capabilities; need to evaluate if/how to use

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
9.1 Complexity and Comprehensiveness
The translated mizer model will be comprehensive, representing:

26 size-structured species (fish, euphausiids, seals, whales, penguins, salps)
1 extended resource spectrum (representing phytoplankton, zooplankton, ice algae, benthic organic matter)
Multiple forcing mechanisms (sea ice, open water, zooplankton dynamics, temperature)
Explicit krill fishery
Full food web from primary producers to apex predators

This is a complex translation that pushes mizer beyond its typical application domain (fish-focused models) to include air-breathing vertebrates. However, this comprehensiveness is justified by:

Calibration requirements: 8 monitored species need to be represented for model validation
Ecosystem approach: WAP ecosystem is truly krill-centric with multiple dependent predator groups
Climate change focus: Sea ice forcing affects multiple groups across taxa
Management relevance: Model designed to inform MPA planning, requiring multi-species representation

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
9.2 Challenges and Innovations
Challenges:

Representing marine mammals and seabirds in size-based framework
Implementing EwE-style forcing in mizer
Calibrating complex model with 26 species

Innovations:

Extended single resource spectrum representing all lower trophic levels (fixes 99.5% resource deficit)
Zooplankton-only forcing strategy to avoid temporal dynamics mismatches
Comprehensive representation of Antarctic food web in mizer including air-breathing vertebrates

title: Step 2: Mizer Model Structure and Conceptual Design
text:
9.3 Comparison to EwE Model

The mizer translation preserves the essential structure of the EwE model while leveraging mizer’s strengths in size-based dynamics and potentially providing additional insights from size spectrum analyses.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
3.4 Total Resource Pool
Combined EwE Resources: ~37,786 t/km²
This represents the complete resource base supporting the consumer community.






NoteTranslation Decision: Extended Single Spectrum



Rather than implementing multiple separate resource spectra (which is not well-supported in standard mizer), we use a single extended resource spectrum that conceptually represents all resource types:

Size coverage: Spans from smallest phytoplankton (1e-10 g) to large zooplankton/organic particles (10 g)
Biomass target: Conservative subset (~5,000-10,000 t/km²) of total EwE resources to ensure adequate food availability
Forcing strategy: Uses zooplankton dynamics only (zmicro + zmeso from ISIMIP) to avoid temporal mismatch between phytoplankton and zooplankton cycles
Ecological justification: Zooplankton biomass already integrates phytoplankton production through trophic interactions; represents the “available prey pool” that consumers actually access

This pragmatic approach: - Fixes the critical resource deficit (initial implementation had only 190 t/km², 99.5% below target) - Works within standard mizer framework - Provides stable forcing based on functional prey availability - Can be refined with size-dependent forcing in future iterations

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
4.1 Size Range
The extended resource spectrum must span from the smallest phytoplankton to sizes large enough to support feeding by the smallest modeled consumer (Antarctic krill, minimum size 0.1 g). The spectrum needs to extend well into prey sizes accessible to krill and small fish:


Define extended resource size range (for illustration)
w_min_resource <- 1e-10  # Smallest phytoplankton (~0.5 μm diameter)
w_max_resource <- 10     # Large zooplankton and organic particles (~20 mm)


This extended range covers:

Picoplankton (1e-10 to 1e-8 g, ~0.5-2 μm): Smallest phytoplankton, bacteria
Nanoplankton (1e-8 to 1e-6 g, ~2-20 μm): Small phytoplankton, flagellates, protozoans
Microplankton (1e-6 to 1e-4 g, ~20-200 μm): Diatoms, dinoflagellates, microzooplankton
Mesoplankton (1e-4 to 0.01 g, ~0.2-5 mm): Copepods, copepod nauplii, larvae
Macroplankton (0.01 to 10 g, ~5-20 mm): Large copepods, euphausiids, organic aggregates

Critical improvement: The original narrow range (1e-8 to 0.001 g) created a 100× size gap between the largest resource and smallest consumer, causing starvation. The extended range provides proper overlap with consumer feeding ranges.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
4.2 Power-Law Parameters

4.2.1 Lambda (λ)
The exponent λ determines the slope of the size spectrum. Typical values for marine ecosystems range from 2.0 to 2.2 (andersen2016?).
Selected value: λ = 2.05
This is consistent with:

Community size spectra theory
Observations in Antarctic waters
Mizer default recommendations



4.2.2 Kappa (κ)
The coefficient κ scales the abundance and is calculated to match a target total resource biomass. For the extended spectrum, we use a conservative estimate that provides adequate food for consumers while representing a subset of total EwE resources:
\[B_{total} = \int_{w_{min}}^{w_{max}} w \cdot \kappa \cdot w^{-\lambda} \, dw = \kappa \int_{w_{min}}^{w_{max}} w^{1-\lambda} \, dw\]
\[B_{total} = \kappa \left[ \frac{w^{2-\lambda}}{2-\lambda} \right]_{w_{min}}^{w_{max}}\]
Solving for κ:
\[\kappa = \frac{B_{total}}{\frac{w_{max}^{2-\lambda} - w_{min}^{2-\lambda}}{2-\lambda}}\]
Target biomass calculation:


Code
# Calculate target biomass
zoo_biomass_ewe <- 190       # g/m² (measured zooplankton)
phyto_multiplier <- 20       # Phyto typically ~20× zoo in productive waters
benthic_background <- 1000   # Accessible benthic/detrital organic matter

target_total <- zoo_biomass_ewe * (1 + phyto_multiplier) + benthic_background
# = 190 * 21 + 1000 = 4,990 g/m² (conservative)

# Calculate kappa
lambda_resource <- 2.05
exponent <- 2 - lambda_resource
biomass_integral <- (w_max_resource^exponent - w_min_resource^exponent) / exponent
kappa_resource <- target_total / biomass_integral


Result: κ ≈ 330 (provides ~5,000 t/km² resources vs. original 8.641 providing only 190 t/km²)
Scaling options:

Conservative: 5,000 t/km² (used initially)
Moderate: 10,000 t/km² (if consumers struggle)
Full: 20,000-30,000 t/km² (closer to EwE total)

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
4.3 Resource Dynamics
In mizer, resource dynamics follow a semi-chemostat model:
\[\frac{dN_R(w)}{dt} = r_{pp}(w) \left[ \kappa(w) - N_R(w) \right] - \mu_R(w)\]
Where:

\(N_R(w)\): Resource abundance at size \(w\)
\(r_{pp}(w)\): Resource growth/replenishment rate
\(\kappa(w)\): Carrying capacity (can be time-varying)
\(\mu_R(w)\): Predation mortality (from consumers)


4.3.1 Growth Rate
The resource growth rate represents the regeneration/turnover rate appropriate for zooplankton dynamics (since we are forcing with zooplankton data):
\[r_{pp} = \frac{\sum (B_i \times P/B_i)}{\sum B_i \times 365}\]
For the three zooplankton groups:
\[r_{pp} = \frac{(25 \times 55) + (130 \times 4.81) + (35 \times 2.5)}{190 \times 365} \approx 0.030 \text{ day}^{-1}\]
This gives an annual turnover rate of approximately 10-11 times per year, which is: - Appropriate for mixed zooplankton communities (micro-zoo: ~50/year, meso-zoo: ~5/year) - Much faster than the initial implementation (0.0301/year, which was 1000× too slow!) - Slower than phytoplankton (50-365/year) but faster than benthic fauna (1-2/year) - Reasonable weighted average for the extended spectrum
Note: While phytoplankton turnover faster (~75/year in EwE), using zooplankton regeneration rate is appropriate because: 1. We’re forcing with zooplankton data (not phytoplankton) 2. Zooplankton biomass already reflects integrated phytoplankton production 3. This avoids temporal mismatch between phyto boom-bust cycles and zoo lagged response

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
5.1 Data Sources
The ISIMIP3a protocol provides monthly plankton biomass from the GFDL-MOM6-COBALT2 Earth System Model:



Variable
Description
Units




phydiat-vint
Diatoms (vertically integrated)
mol C m⁻²


phydiaz-vint
Diazotrophs
mol C m⁻²


phypico-vint
Picophytoplankton
mol C m⁻²


zmicro-vint
Microzooplankton
mol C m⁻²


zmeso-vint
Mesozooplankton
mol C m⁻²



Period: 1961-2010 (monthly)
Spatial resolution: 15 arcmin
Domain: Western Antarctic Peninsula

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
5.2 Biomass Conversion
Carbon content is converted to biomass using the molecular weight of carbon (12 g/mol):
\[B_{g/m^2} = C_{mol/m^2} \times 12 \, \text{g/mol}\]

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
5.3 Time-Varying Resource Capacity
To incorporate environmental forcing, we make the resource carrying capacity time-varying using zooplankton data only:
\[\kappa(t) = \kappa_{baseline} \times f(t)\]
Where \(f(t)\) is a scaling factor based on zooplankton biomass from ISIMIP:
\[f(t) = \frac{B_{zmicro}(t) + B_{zmeso}(t)}{\overline{B_{zmicro} + B_{zmeso}}}\]
Why zooplankton forcing only?

Trophic integration: Zooplankton biomass already integrates phytoplankton dynamics through feeding and reproduction (weeks lag)
Consumer relevance: Most modeled species feed on zooplankton, not directly on phytoplankton (krill eat copepods, not diatoms)
Temporal stability: Zooplankton shows dampened dynamics (CV ~0.5) vs. phytoplankton boom-bust (CV >1.0)
Avoids mismatch: Single forcing cannot capture opposing phyto-zoo dynamics simultaneously (when phyto crashes post-bloom, zoo peaks)

This approach:

Maintains the baseline resource spectrum structure
Scales the carrying capacity with functional prey availability
Incorporates climate-driven changes in resource production
Provides stable, biologically-relevant bottom-up forcing







ImportantImplementation Decision



Time-varying capacity will be implemented in later calibration steps (Step 7). Initial model runs will use constant capacity to establish baseline dynamics.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
6.1 Biomass Estimates
Comparing the resource biomass from different sources:
EwE Zooplankton: 190 g/m²

Micro-zoo: 25 g/m²
Meso-zoo: 130 g/m²
Macro-zoo: 35 g/m²

ISIMIP Plankton (1961-2010 mean):

Microzooplankton: ~1.5 g C/m² = 18 g/m² (biomass)
Mesozooplankton: ~0.2 g C/m² = 2.4 g/m² (biomass)
Total zoo: ~20 g/m²







WarningBiomass Discrepancy



There is an order of magnitude difference between EwE and ISIMIP zooplankton biomass. Possible reasons:

Unit conversion issues: Need to verify C:biomass conversion factors
Spatial averaging: ISIMIP averages over large grid cells including deep water
EwE calibration: EwE biomass may be calibrated to shelf/coastal areas
Model representation: COBALT may underestimate polar zooplankton
Carbon-to-wet-weight: May need different conversion (typically 1:5-1:10 for zooplankton)

Resolution: Use EwE biomass as baseline for initial parameterization, then calibrate against observations during model tuning. ISIMIP forcing will be used for relative temporal variation, not absolute values.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
7.1 Basic Setup


Example code for setting up resource spectrum in mizer (for illustration)
# Load resource parameters
resource_params <- readRDS(file.path(MODEL_DIR, "resource_params.rds"))

# Create mizer params object
params <- newMultispeciesParams(
  species_params = species_params,
  interaction = interaction_matrix,
  
  # Resource spectrum parameters
  kappa = resource_params$kappa,
  lambda = resource_params$lambda,
  w_pp_cutoff = resource_params$w_pp_cutoff,
  resource_rate = resource_params$r_pp,
  
  # Other parameters...
)

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
7.2 Time-Varying Capacity (Optional)
For simulations with environmental forcing:


Example code for time-varying resource capacity (for illustration)
# Extract time series
capacity_ts <- resource_params$capacity$time_series

# Create time-varying capacity function
resource_capacity_fn <- function(params, t, ...) {
  # Get the time index
  time_idx <- which.min(abs(capacity_ts$time - t))
  scaling <- capacity_ts$scaling_factor[time_idx]
  
  # Scale the baseline capacity
  return(resource_params$kappa * scaling)
}

# Set in params
params <- setResource(params,
                     resource_capacity = resource_capacity_fn,
                     resource_rate = resource_params$r_pp)

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
8.2 Resource Spectrum Shape






Figure 1: Resource Spectrum Shape



As shown in Figure 1, the resource spectrum follows the expected power-law distribution \(N(w) = \kappa w^{-\lambda}\) across the size range from 10⁻⁸ to 10⁻³ g. The slope parameter λ = 2.05 is consistent with marine size spectra theory and observations in Antarctic waters.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
8.3 Biomass Distribution by Size






Figure 2: Biomass Distribution by Size



Figure 2 shows how resource biomass is distributed across different size classes. The total integrated biomass equals the target value of 190 g/m² from the EwE model, ensuring consistency with the food web energetics baseline.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
8.4 Temporal Dynamics: ISIMIP Plankton Forcing






Figure 3: ISIMIP Plankton Time Series



The ISIMIP3a plankton forcing data shown in Figure 3 (GFDL-MOM6-COBALT2 model, 1961-2010) shows:

Microzooplankton: Mean ~1.5 g C/m² (18 g/m² biomass)
Mesozooplankton: Mean ~0.2 g C/m² (2.4 g/m² biomass)
Total zooplankton: ~20 g/m² (ISIMIP)

The time series exhibits clear seasonal cycles with interannual variation, providing a basis for time-varying resource capacity in future simulations.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
8.5 Biomass Comparison: EwE vs ISIMIP






Figure 4: Biomass Comparison



Figure 4 reveals a significant discrepancy between data sources:



Source
Zooplankton Biomass
Total Plankton Biomass




EwE Model
190 g/m²
—


ISIMIP (zmicro + zmeso)
~20 g/m²
~150 g/m²



This order-of-magnitude difference is attributed to:

Carbon-to-biomass conversion: Simple 12:1 conversion may underestimate actual biomass
Spatial scale: ISIMIP averages over large grid cells including deep water; EwE focuses on shelf/coastal areas
Model structure: COBALT may underrepresent polar zooplankton productivity
Calibration differences: EwE biomass calibrated to local observations

Resolution: We use the EwE baseline (190 g/m²) for initial parameterization to maintain consistency with the food web structure. ISIMIP forcing will be applied as relative temporal variation (scaling factors) rather than absolute values during environmental forcing implementation.

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
8.6 Validation Outcomes
Expected after extended spectrum implementation:

✓ Biomass adequacy: Resource spectrum provides ~5,000 t/km² (26× increase from 190)
✓ Size distribution: Power-law with appropriate slope (λ = 2.05)
✓ Turnover rate: Resource rate of 10 year⁻¹ appropriate for zooplankton dynamics
✓ Size range: Extended coverage from phytoplankton (10⁻¹⁰ g) to large zooplankton (10 g)
✓ Consumer access: Resources now overlap with consumer feeding ranges (krill can feed on 0.01-1 g prey)
✓ Trophic pyramid: Proper structure with resources > consumers (not inverted)
✓ Energy flow: Production (~50,000 t/km²/year) >> demand (~2,000 t/km²/year)
✓ Temporal forcing: ISIMIP zooplankton data provides stable, relevant forcing

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
9.1 Decisions

Use extended single spectrum: Represents all resources (phyto, zoo, benthic, detritus) in one continuum
Size range 10^-10 to 10 g: Expanded to include full range from phytoplankton to large zooplankton
Lambda = 2.05: Standard value for marine size spectra (retained)
Kappa scaled for adequate biomass: Target ~5,000 t/km² to support consumers (not just 190)
Zooplankton forcing only: Avoids temporal mismatch between phyto and zoo dynamics
Conservative biomass target: Use subset of EwE total initially, can increase if needed

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
9.2 Assumptions

Size spectrum theory applies: Extended spectrum still follows power-law distribution
Semi-chemostat dynamics: Resources have carrying capacity and regeneration rate
Spatial homogeneity: Resource parameters uniform across model domain
Zooplankton as functional prey: Zoo biomass represents “available food” for consumers
Trophic integration: Zoo dynamics capture integrated phytoplankton production signal
Single forcing adequate: Zooplankton forcing can represent entire extended spectrum (Phase 1)

title: Step 4: Resource Spectrum Parameterization
text:
9.3 Uncertainties

Optimal target biomass: Range from 5,000 to 30,000 t/km² defensible; may need calibration
Regeneration rate: Using zoo rate (10/year) vs. size-dependent rates
Size spectrum slope: λ = 2.05 may need adjustment for extended range
Forcing strategy: Single zoo forcing vs. future size-dependent forcing (phyto for small, zoo for large)
Benthic representation: Lumped into spectrum vs. future explicit species
Ice algae seasonality: Not explicitly captured in Phase 1 implementation

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
1.1 Objectives

Assemble all parameters into a MizerParams object
Set initial conditions based on EwE biomass distributions
Validate model structure and parameter consistency
Find steady state (or quasi-steady state) through simulation
Generate diagnostics for initial model performance
Compare with EwE equilibrium conditions

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
2.1 MizerParams Object
The MizerParams object is the core data structure in mizer that contains all model parameters and settings. Key components include:

2.1.1 Species Parameters
From Step 3, includes for each species:

Size parameters: \(w_{min}\), \(w_{mat}\), \(w_{\infty}\)
Growth parameters: \(K\), \(h\), \(ks\)
Mortality parameters: \(z_0\)
Feeding parameters: \(\beta\), \(\sigma\)
Reproduction parameters: \(e_{repro}\)



2.1.2 Interaction Matrix
From Step 5, defines species-to-species feeding preferences \(\theta_{ij}\) modulating predation rates between species \(i\) (predator) and \(j\) (prey).


2.1.3 Resource Spectrum
From Step 4, characterizes the background resource (phytoplankton and zooplankton):

\(\kappa\): Carrying capacity
\(\lambda\): Size spectrum slope

\(r_{pp}\): Regeneration rate
\(w_{pp,cutoff}\): Maximum resource size

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
2.2 Size Discretization
Mizer represents populations using size-based abundances \(N_i(w)\) where:

\(N_i(w)\): Abundance of species \(i\) at size \(w\) (number per gram per km²)
Size classes span from \(w_{min}\) to beyond \(w_{\infty}\) for each species
Logarithmic size binning ensures adequate resolution across orders of magnitude

Model configuration:

Number of size bins: 200 (increased from default for better resolution)
Size range: 1e-4 g to 2e8 g (0.1 mg to 200 tonnes)
Resource range: 1e-14 g to 1e1 g (capturing phytoplankton to large zooplankton)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
2.3 Initial Conditions
Initial size distributions are critical for model dynamics. We use EwE biomass to constrain total biomass per species, then distribute across sizes following ecological scaling assumptions.

2.3.1 Biomass Distribution Strategy
For each species:

Get EwE total biomass (tonnes/km²)
Generate initial size distribution using mizer defaults (typically power law)
Scale distribution to match EwE total biomass
Validate biomass allocation across size classes

The default size distribution assumes:
\[N_i(w) \propto w^{-\mu}\]
where \(\mu\) typically ranges from 1-3, reflecting:

Size-dependent mortality

Growth rates
Reproductive allocation

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
3.1 Input Components

3.1.1 Species Parameters


Load and summarize species parameters
# Read species parameters
species_params <- read.csv(file.path(MODEL_DIR, "species_parameters.csv"))

# Create summary table by category
summary_table <- species_params %>%
  group_by(category) %>%
  summarize(
    `N Species` = n(),
    `Size Range` = paste0(
      signif(min(w_min), 2), " - ",
      signif(max(w_inf), 2), " g"
    ),
    `Mean K` = signif(mean(k_vb), 3),
    `Mean z0` = signif(mean(z0), 3)
  )

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
3.2 Parameter Validation
Before assembly, key validations performed:

Size consistency: \(w_{min} < w_{mat} < w_{\infty}\) for all species ✓
Growth parameters: \(K > 0\), \(h > 0\) for all species ✓

Mortality rates: \(z_0 > 0\) and ecologically reasonable ✓
Feeding parameters: \(\beta > 0\), \(0.5 < \sigma < 3\) ✓
Interaction matrix: Square, no cannibalism, reasonable sparsity ✓

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
3.3 Model Creation
The MizerParams object is created using:


Example code for creating MizerParams object (for illustration)
params <- newMultispeciesParams(
  species_params = species_params,
  interaction = interaction_matrix,
  kappa = resource_params$kappa,
  lambda = resource_params$lambda,
  w_pp_cutoff = resource_params$w_pp_cutoff,
  r_pp = resource_params$r_pp,
  no_w = 200,
  min_w = 1e-4,
  max_w = 2e8,
  min_w_pp = 1e-14
)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
4.1 Biomass Scaling from EwE
Initial abundances were scaled to match EwE biomass estimates:

4.1.1 Initial Biomass Comparison






Figure 1: Initial biomass comparison between EwE and Mizer models



Figure 1 shows species-by-species comparison of biomass (tonnes/km²) between the EwE model and our initial mizer setup. Species are grouped by functional category (fish, krill, seals, whales, penguins, birds, other).


4.1.2 Biomass Ratios
Key Statistics (Initial Mizer / EwE) are calculated by the setup script and documented in the model summary output.

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
4.2 Initial Size Spectrum






Figure 2: Initial size spectrum by species



Figure 2 shows the abundance-size distribution for all species in the initial model state. The plot uses Sheldon spectrum notation (abundance × weight² vs weight) which produces flat spectra under equilibrium conditions.
Key features:

Power = 2: Sheldon spectrum normalization
Total line: Community-level size spectrum (black line)
Species lines: Individual species contributions (colored)
Resource spectrum: Background plankton (typically leftmost portion)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
4.3 Validation Tests

4.3.1 Test Simulation
A short 1-year test simulation was performed to verify:

✓ No numerical instabilities
✓ No negative abundances

✓ Reasonable feeding rates
✓ Energy conservation
✓ Mass balance

Result: Success (documented in model summary output)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
5.1 Approach
Finding a true steady state in multi-species size-spectrum models is challenging due to:

Complex dynamics: 26 interacting species with different life histories
Size structure: Each species has multiple size classes (cohorts)
Predator-prey cycles: Natural oscillations in some interactions
Stochasticity: Inherent variability in ecological dynamics


5.1.1 Strategy
We use a quasi-steady state approach:

Run model for 100 years from EwE-scaled initial conditions
Monitor biomass trajectories for stability
Calculate coefficient of variation (CV) for last 20 years
Accept if mean CV < 0.1 (within 10% variation)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
5.2 Simulation Results

5.2.1 Biomass Time Series






Figure 3: Biomass trajectories during steady state run



Figure 3 shows time series of total biomass for each species over 100-year simulation. Stable trajectories indicate equilibrium or quasi-equilibrium conditions.


5.2.2 Stability Assessment
Coefficient of variation and overall assessment are calculated by the setup script and documented in the model summary output.






NoteNatural Variability



Multi-species models often exhibit some variability even at “steady state” due to:

Predator-prey cycles (especially krill-predator interactions)
Cohort effects (recruitment pulses)
Size-dependent interactions
Reproductive stochasticity

A model with CV < 0.1-0.2 is generally considered acceptably stable for calibration purposes.

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
5.3 Steady State Biomass

5.3.1 Comparison with EwE






Figure 4: Steady state biomass compared to EwE



Figure 4 compares biomass distributions after equilibration with EwE to assess how the model settles relative to the reference state. Detailed biomass change analysis is documented in the model summary output.

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
5.4 Steady State Size Spectrum






Figure 5: Steady state size spectrum



Figure 5 shows the size spectrum after equilibration and how the community structure stabilizes. Comparison with the initial spectrum (Figure 2) reveals:

Shifts in abundance across size classes
Emergence of stable predator-prey structure

Balance between growth, reproduction, and mortality

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
6.1 Growth Curves






Figure 6: Growth curves by species



Figure 6 shows von Bertalanffy growth curves displaying expected mass-at-age for selected species. These curves result from the interaction of:

Maximum consumption rate (\(h\))
Feeding level (realized intake)
Metabolic costs
Size-dependent parameters

Validation: Compare with known growth rates from literature for key species (Antarctic Krill, icefish, etc.)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
6.2 Feeding Level






Figure 7: Feeding level by species and size



Figure 7 shows feeding level (\(f\)), which represents the ratio of realized consumption to maximum possible consumption:
\[f = \frac{\text{Actual intake}}{\text{Maximum intake}}\]
Interpretation:

f ≈ 1: Satiated, food abundant
f ≈ 0.5: Moderate food availability

f < 0.3: Food-limited, may indicate issues
f > 0.95: Potentially over-feeding

Expected patterns:

Small individuals (juveniles): Higher f (abundant small prey)
Large individuals: Lower f (fewer suitable prey)
Specialists: Variable f (dependent on specific prey)
Generalists: Stable f (can switch prey)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
6.3 Energy Balance
Key energy flows in the model:

6.3.1 Consumption
\[C_i(w) = h_i(w) \times f_i(w) \times w\]
Where \(h_i(w)\) is maximum intake rate and \(f_i(w)\) is feeding level.


6.3.2 Growth
\[g_i(w) = \left[\varepsilon_i(w) \times C_i(w) - k_i(w) \times w\right] / w\]
Where \(\varepsilon\) is assimilation efficiency and \(k\) is metabolic rate.


6.3.3 Reproduction
\[R_i = \int_{w_{mat}}^{w_{\infty}} E_{R,i}(w) \times N_i(w) \times dw\]
Where \(E_{R,i}(w)\) is energy allocated to reproduction.


6.3.4 Mortality
Total mortality includes:

Predation mortality (\(\mu_{pred}\)): Death due to predators
Background mortality (\(\mu_{background} = z_0\)): All other sources

Fishing mortality (\(F\)): To be added in calibration step

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
6.4 Validation Checks

6.4.1 Mass Balance
For each species, verify:
\[\frac{dB}{dt} = \text{Growth} + \text{Recruitment} - \text{Deaths}\]
At steady state: \(\frac{dB}{dt} \approx 0\)


6.4.2 Energy Conservation
Community-level energy should be conserved:
\[\text{Primary Production} = \text{Consumption} + \text{Respiration} + \text{Mortality}\]


6.4.3 Trophic Structure
Trophic level comparison with EwE is documented in the model summary output.

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
7.1 Key Metrics
Key metrics and assessment are documented in the model summary output file model_setup_summary.txt.

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
7.2 Comparison with EwE
Detailed comparison of similarities, differences, and interpretation are documented in the model summary output. Key differences between mizer and EwE arise from:

Size structure: Mizer explicitly models size classes
Functional forms: Different equations for growth, consumption
Temporal dynamics: Continuous vs discrete time steps
Spatial scale: Both models represent WAP ecosystem average

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
8.2 Usage
To load and use the model:


Example code for loading and using the model (for illustration)
# Load steady state model
params <- readRDS("Models/AI-assisted/Attempt 1/steady_state_params.rds")

# Run a simulation
sim <- project(params, t_max = 50)

# Plot results
plotBiomass(sim)
plotSpectra(sim)

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
9.1 Size Discretization
Decision: Use 200 size bins spanning 1e-4 g to 2e8 g
Rationale: - Higher resolution than default (100 bins) for complex food web - Captures full size range from small zooplankton to large whales - Sufficient resolution for size-based feeding interactions
Trade-off: Increased computational cost vs accuracy

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
9.2 Initial Conditions
Decision: Scale size distributions to match EwE total biomass
Rationale: - Maintains consistency with validated EwE model - Provides realistic starting point - Allows direct comparison of model outputs
Alternative: Could use observed size distributions if available

title: Step 6: Initial Model Setup and Steady State
text:
9.3 Steady State Criterion
Decision: Accept quasi-steady state with mean CV < 0.1
Rationale: - True steady state may not exist for complex multi-species system - Natural variability is ecologically realistic
- Stable enough for calibration and scenario analysis
Alternative: Could run longer or use optimization to force equilibrium
